awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engaging Introductory Astronomy Students in Authentic Research through Citizen Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will build upon the infrastructure of Zooniverse.org to create authentic research experiences for introductory astronomy students. Education research indicates that including authentic research in science classes improves attitudes towards science and scientists in a diverse cross-section of students. The curriculum materials will be tested and refined at a broad spectrum of institutional settings before dissemination.  

Introductory astronomy generally provides students little insight into the realities of being a scientist. This project will address this deficiency by introducing an authentic research experience for students into the astronomy for non-majors curriculum. It will utilize the classification and meta-data exploration capabilities of the Zooniverse platform. The proposed course curriculum will support students in building foundational research skills and practices through a series of in-class activities and a semester-long group research project. These activities will employ a state-of-the-art online platform to explore data collection, manipulation, and interpretation within the core topics in the curriculum. The project team will assess student learning and attitudinal gains through traditional in-class testing and conceptual questioning that is embedded within the Zooniverse online environment, as well as student interviews. This includes assessing the impact of the research experience on students' understanding of the nature of science, conceptual astronomy learning gains (e.g. the Zooniverse Astronomical Concept Survey, Prather et al, 2013), and interest in pursuing a STEM major. The team will also assess the impact of different implementations of the online platform as well as the ease of implementation of the new curricular materials in a variety of institutional settings, course structures, and content focus. They will use the insight gained to develop the most effective curricular and training materials. All curricular materials, instructional guides, online Zooniverse tools, and underlying code will be widely disseminated.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Through its engagement of over 1.7 million citizen scientists and hundreds of professional researchers in 234 countries around the world, the Zooniverse.org online citizen science platform has facilitated the meaningful participation of non­-academics in the scientific process over the past decade. With over 80 active projects across the disciplines (from astronomy to zoology, climate science to cancer research, arts to the humanities), the Zooniverse engages the public in meaningful and valued ways in real research. Citizen science bridges the gap between science and society, enriching the public’s understanding not only of scientific facts but the scientific process. NSF­-funded efforts like this one enable us to move forward in our understanding and use of citizen science to support the development of a scientifically and data literate society, crucial to the country's health and economy. Through this NSF-IUSE funded effort, we developed, implemented, and assessed the impact of a citizen science based authentic research experience for undergraduate students in introductory astronomy courses for non-STEM majors. Here we used the Zooniverse.org platform for students to participate in the Galaxy Zoo citizen science project, access astronomical data, test hypotheses, analyze data, and draw conclusions. By developing an authentic research experience using real data and aligning the activities with what scientists actually do, we avoided a common pitfall of active learning activities in lecture-based courses: confirmatory exercises in which students follow explicit procedures to arrive at predetermined conclusions. We also directly addressed the need to develop a scientifically and data literate populace with a real experience of the nature of science. Through the Classroom.Zooniverse.Org portal, students and instructors can access the Astro 101 citizen science curricular materials, instructors’ guides, track progress on assignments, etc. A general overview of the curricular materials and impact are highlighted in Trouille et al. (under review) 'Citizen Science in Astronomy Education' chapter in an upcoming book to be published by the Institute of Physics (IoP) titled "Astronomy Education Volume 2: A Practitioner’s Guide to the Research". The chapter broadly describes efforts incorporating citizen science into astronomy classroom environments, with a particular focus on Zooniverse-based initiatives. Nelson et al. (in prep), to be submitted to the Journal of Geoscience Education, provides an overview of the curriculum developed through this NSF-IUSE funded effort and feedback from instructors on ease-of-use and implementation. It also presents the results from the analyses of our pre/post surveys and focus group interviews. Broadly we find the citizen science based small group research experience to have a positive impact on student learning and attitudes.

This NSF-IUSE effort has laid the foundation for our next NSF-IUSE funded effort to expand these curricular materials beyond astronomy to introductory geoscience and biology courses for non-STEM majors, examining the impact of having the majority of non-STEM majors (a critical mass of students) on a given campus sharing a common language, exposure to, and understanding of citizen science. How does membership in a citizen science aware (and potentially engaged) community impact students’ attitudes towards science and scientists, the role of society in science, and their own science (and citizen scientist) identity development and potential for lifelong engagement and advocacy? See https://nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1821319&HistoricalAwards=false for an overview.
